pros: The homes are not crowded

pros:
- Rewarding work
- Benefits package 
- Flexible working
- Pay is okay
cons:
- Training is horrific: its rushed, mostly online modules. Moving and handling training is difficult to book onto
- Some staff are treated better than others
- Management turn a blind eye to poor practice due to short staffing
- Cliquey
- Long hours
- Some leaders lack people skills, lack professionalism and don't appreciate honesty
-  Staff don't challenge the care of service users, a kind of "this is the way we've done things so why change it" mentality

pros: CIC invests alot in training staff
cons: Recruitment process is quite slow

pros: Plenty of hours, flexible and big team
cons: Difficult staff, not always approachable

pros: They are good always pay you on time and management listen to you as well
cons: Could do with a wage increase

review_title: A really good company to work for
pros:
Valuing their staff
Training 
Support given to people 
Organisational values and ethics
Honest and transparent 
Are prepared to go farther than other social care employers
Visionary, compassionate, Loyal and forward thinking Chief Executive
cons: Some of the leadership need to get onboard with the overall vision of the organisation

job_title: Community Support Worker in Nottingham, England
pros: Flexible rotas for students working on bank contract
cons: Shift hours can be long

pros: Excellent team, making things easier to understand and enjoy your job
cons: Company looks after themselves incase things go wrong

Enjoyed time with residents
Great team

pros: Culture, values and purpose and strong leadership
cons: Slightly orientated to Paris and competitive sector

pros: A really caring company to work for. I've never been praised so much - they really make you feel valued and care about your progression.
cons: Working towards fairer pay for social care through lobbying the government.

review_title: Keen to be on the right side of history
pros:
Proud to be a part of making a positive difference to peoples lives.
CEO is very visible and publicly fights for the people we support.
Work can be varied and unique day to day.
Very friendly office colleagues, departments regularly work together to fulfil an assignment.
Management are very flexible and understanding around family/life curveballs.
cons: Forward planning could be better. Although the nature of the sector is understandably hard to predict, projects are often pushed to such short timescales there is a tendency to jump in to producing before a clear plan has been finalised.

pros:
Leading uk charity
Do great work 
Some great people there
cons:
Poor pay
Un- even distribution of salaries across organisation
No scope for progression

pros: You feel like you really make a difference in peoples lives, every day is new and different
cons: The peoe you support become like a second. Family and you truly care avout them, sometimes you can't help but take your work home

pros: Scope to progress in the organisation
cons: Ambitions of the organisation can at time make them lose focus of person centered approaches to both staff and people supported

job_title: ER Advisor Project Manager in Widnes, England
pros: Caring not for profit employer
cons: No issues to report here

job_title: Human Resources Advisor in Durham, England
pros: Excellent work life balance, caring managers
cons: None, but support workers deserve better pay and the government need to support this

review_title: 12 years of my life down the drain
job_title: Senior Support Worker in Hartlepool, England
pros:
People being supported make the job worth while.

Managers who actually know what they are doing and care about the people are incredible.
cons:
Paperwork takes presidence over actually caring for the people.

There is no consistency in terms of consequences, it's one rule for some and one for others if you're in the managers good books. 

Some staff have overtime forced upon them, when staff refuse due to family commitments they are made to feel incredibly guilty and pressured to say yes.

Manager was made aware of bad practices chose to ignore them and then punished someone for the same thing.

pros: was good for 2 years than management left was terrible
cons:
fired and made very ill now on meds for life.
accused me of contacting pws when I didnt and when I proved I didnt they did nothing about it.
forced me to sign papers to conduct a mental health assessment and threw me out when I refused

review_title: Love working with people we support
job_title: Community Support Worker in Wick, Scotland
pros: The people we support are amazing
cons: Management awful, all family and friends, never taken seriously

review_title: Great residents, terrible gossipy culture! No support and career progression

Petty gossip!
No help for new starters!
No support!
Unrealistic expectations!

job_title: Service Manager in Warrington, North West England, England

Higher management is team of narcistic, bullies in a click. 
Cant have own thoughts or opinions 
Not allowed to speak up against poor practise for fear of being targeted
Good staff want out.
Face has to fit.
Poor pay and unreasonable demands
Culture of being old to never challenge and to shut up and do as told
Ceo is aware of issues. But seems to just close his eyes to it all

job_title: Community Service Leader in Liverpool, England

pros: Great team and people we support
cons: Money, management and not fun

pros: Laidback and informal.  Flexible and accommodating around working hours to suit  family/childcare needs short or long term.  A lot of  extra responsibilities available  if you like that kind of challenge.
cons:
Management, really.  Dictatorsh- sorry, leadership is an issue. Lack of communication. No team spirit. Them and Us culture. 
 Varied rates of pay but at SW level, all below "living wage".  A lot of paperwork and little  time to do it. A lot of responsibility for not a lot of money.

review_title: Good senior management, poor on the floor staff
pros: Friendly service manager who offers 24/7 support if you have any concerns or problems.  Small organisation with a wide variety of different service users helping you to gain experience in a variety of conditions. Good training.
cons: Variable shifts from day to day which is very tiring, a lot of pressure is put onto you from day one especially if you're a driver. Staff members are not the most encouraging and are constantly telling you different ways of doing tasks for the service users. This is very confusing as a lot of different information is thrown at you when you join the company.

pros: The people I supported
cons:
Do not care about the employees even when pointed out the lack of support for the residents the inadequacy of the home they where in no proper systems in place pec cards ,toilet visits  visual aids etc non verbals being treated like donkeys I.e. carrot to get them to do anything 
No wonder they did not want to do anything unless you bribed them they came to expect it rather than using visual aids management just not interested

review_title: A big heart and bold ambition!
pros:
Visionary CEO.
Commitment to People - supported and people who work for us.
Exciting new strategy.
Game changers - staff forum getting a good deal for frontline staff
cons: Funding of social care sector is a challenge but really optimistic about where the company is, and the plans for the future.

job_title: Human Resources & Training in Edinburgh, Scotland

Unprofessional Company
Lack of structure

Very few people with 2years+ length of service

pros: fabulous people supported and pockets of good team work.
